statement.tex: %text Find the equation of the normal at a point on the curve $x^2=4y$ which passes through the point $(1,2)$. Also, find the equation of the corresponding tangent. %

step.context: %text The figure(s) below show the curve $x^2=4y$ and the tangent (T) and normal (N) at a point. But where will the point $A=(1,2)$ be? %
step.reason:
%text Notice that when $(x,y) = (1,2)$, then $x^2\neq 4y$. In other words, point $A=(1,2)$ \underline\text{cannot be} on the parabola $y = \frac{x^2}{4}$.
However, $\left( 1,\frac{1^2}{4}\right) = \left(1,\frac{1}{4}\right)$ will be on the parabola. And as $A=(1,2)$ \underline\text{lies directly above} \left(1,\frac{1}{4}\right), therefore point $A$ will be as shown in the correct option. %

step.context: %text If the required normal touches the parabola at point $P=(x_P,y_P)$, then would the following be true (see equation below)? %
%text Given that $\dfrac{y_P - 2}{x_P-1} = -\dfrac{2}{x_P}$, what will the coordinates of point $P$ be? %
\textbf{Right or wrong?}\\ %text Given that $A=(1,2)$ and $P=(2,1)$, the equations of the required normal and tangent would be as follows. %
step.reason: %text We know that $AP$ is the normal and we know what $A$ and $P$ are. Hence, finding the equation for the normal should be easy. % \begin{align} \frac{y-y_P}{x-x_P} &= \frac{y_P-y_A}{x_P-x_A} \\ \implies\frac{y-1}{x-2} &= \frac{1-2}{2-1} = -1 \\ \therefore y &= -x + 3\text{ or }x + y = 3 \end{align} \\ %text \underline\text{As for the tangent}, we know that % \begin{align} m_T &= \left[\frac{dy}{dx}\right]_{P} = \left[ \frac{x_P}{2}\right] = 1 \\ \therefore \frac{y-y_P}{x-x_P} &= m_T = 1 \\ \implies \frac{y-1}{x-2} &= 1\text{ or }y=x-1 \end{align}
